awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  The evolution of gene expression in Sccharomyces cerevisiae experimental evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.  Understanding the genetics that determine how organisms adapt to a changing environment is a challenging problem in evolutionary biology, but essential for predicting future evolutionary change.  The Fellow will use laboratory evolution experiments to determine the long-term evolutionary response of yeast populations, reproducing in different ways, when exposed to environmental stressors. To increase participation from members of underrepresented groups in biology, the Fellow will conduct workshops in collaboration with the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) at Oregon State University to train undergraduates from such groups in computational methods common in biological data science. 

Findings from laboratory evolution experiments suggest a fundamental difference in the genetics of adaptation between populations of organisms that reproduce by mitosis or budding versus those that involve meiosis. Adaptation in the former is fueled by de novo beneficial mutation, while standing genetic variation drives the process in the latter. Experimental study systems involving meiosis are required to model evolutionary change in higher eukaryotic organisms using this mode of reproduction.  However, experiments that feature such systems are limited by scale; carrying out powerful experiments is difficult with complex eukaryotes.  Thus, there is a need for large, highly-replicated experiments that feature reproduction involving meiosis.  In addition, despite strong evidence that changes in gene regulation drive adaptation to selective pressures, laboratory evolution experiments rarely feature gene expression assays. The Fellow seeks to address these gaps with evolution experiments employing Saccharomyces cerevisiae to address the following questions: (1) How repeatable is the evolutionary response across a range of selective pressures? (2) How do patterns of gene expression change across different stages of adaptation? And (3) What are the relative contributions of changes in cis and trans regulation in driving adaptation? The Fellow will recruit students from OSU's LSAMP program to contribute to this research endeavor as a means of further promoting the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how organisms adapt to new environmental conditions and stressors has long been a major area of interest for evolutionary biologists. This topic is especially relevant today due to growing interest in developing models to predict how species will respond to rapid environmental shifts being brought about by climate change. Within this are of research, an example of an ideal outcome would be the ability to predict a population?s ability to adapt to increasing temperatures based on patterns of genetic variation at a given instant. However, achieving such outcomes almost certainly requires a more nuanced understanding of the genetic architecture of adaptation than we currently possess. As an NSF postdoctoral research fellow at Oregon State University, my research efforts were aimed at generating insights to get us closer to that goal.

            My primary research project dealt with understanding how the genetic architecture of adaption in impacted by the intensity of selection (e.g. moderate versus large increase in temperature). Specifically, I subjected yeast populations in the lab to different levels of ethanol stress and studied resulting changes in patterns of genetic variation and gene expression over several hundred generations as they adapted to their new environments. As I used outcrossing yeast populations created by combining several diverse clonal strains, I was able to study dynamics associated with adaptation from standing genetic variation despite working in a microbial system. This is in contrast to experiments in strictly asexual populations where adaptation would result almost exclusively from novel beneficial mutations. In terms of more specific goals, I was interested in assessing how will observations fit the following scenarios: 1.) due to trade-offs between ethanol resistance and other life-history traits, different genes are involved in adaptation to different levels of ethanol stress, and 2.) the same genetic variants drive adaptation regardless of selection intensity, but there are greater shifts in the frequency of these variants when selection is more intense. The former is consistent with a model of adaptation that assumes wide-spread antagonist pleiotropy (i.e. individual genetic variants are impacting multiple traits in antagonistic ways), while the latter is more consistent with a polygenic adaptation and genetic redundancies (i.e. all beneficial variants do not need to fix in a population due to redundancies, but greater shifts in frequency are needed when selection is intense for the mean fitness of the population reach its new optimal level). While I find some limited evidence of Scenario 1, Scenario 2 is more representative of adaptation in this particular system.

            Outside of my primary research project, I have contributed to and led various projects that have produced findings and resources that should be of value to others attempting to do evolution experiments with outcrossing yeast populations. Beyond my work at Oregon State University, I also contributed to several collaborative efforts focused on the dissecting genetic basis of longevity differences and fungal resistance in fruit flies. Manuscripts resulting from these efforts are all either published or in the process of being published, and will hopefully be of interest and value to the broader scientific community.

            In addition to my research efforts and in keeping with the Broadening Participation aspect of my appointment, I have engaged in a number of activities to promote diversity and inclusion in STEM. Over the course of my two year appointment, I recruited and trained three undergraduates from Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) chapter at Oregon State University to work with me in the lab. One of these students in now pursuing graduate programs in molecular biology, and the other two are applying to professional programs in medicine. At the institutional level, I was a member of Oregon State University?s DEJI Action Plan Committee, and I am one of the authors of the action plan to promote diversity and inclusion at all levels within the College of Science. Lastly, I served on a committee in my home department, Integrative Biology, tasked with evaluating and updating hiring and recruitment policies to promote increased diversity at the level of research and teaching faculty.
